The Chinese characters for wisdom is written as 智慧.
  −
:知+日=智(zhì) knowledge on top sun below, means radiant conscious intelligence, represents the yang part of the visible tip of an iceberg .
  −
:丰+丰+手+心=慧 (huì) two harvests on top hand in middle mind or heart below, means the harvest of deeper wisdom and ability for being aware of the unconscious or self-nature, represents the yin part of the invisible iceberg below.
  −   −
Some of the central teachings of Confucius in Chinese characters are:
  −
:人+二=仁 (rén) man on left two on right, the relationship between two human beings, means humanity, benevolence, seed. Originally the the character was just written as丨二 representing yin yang, the vertical line is yang (male, penis, heaven, odd numbers), the two horizontal lines are yin (female, vagina, earth, even numbers), 仁 is the seed and core of everything. The character 人 (man, rén) and 仁 have the same pronunciation, whenever Chinese characters have similar sounds they have similar meanings. Thus when a human is unable to be humane, he or she does not qualify to be a human but an animal. But when a human is able to be humane, for example, when Buddhism first introduced to China in the Han Dynasty the Chinese people translated the Buddha's name into "able to be human" or someone with ”ability and humanity" (能人，能仁) because Confucius's teachings and the Buddha's teachings are "one to two, two to one."
  −
:如+心=恕 (shù) like or as if on top heart or mind below, means forgiveness and consideration. Confucius said,"Don't do to others what you don't want others do to you."
  −
:人+言=信 (xìn) man on left word or speech on right, means trustworthiness and integrity.

The three poisons in Chinese characters are 貪怒痴:
  −
:今+貝=貪 (tān) today or current moment on top treasure chest standing below, means greed.
  −
:奴+心=怒 (nù) slave on top mind below, means anger.
  −
:知+疒=痴 (chī) knowledge inside a sickbed, so knowledge lying on sickbed means ignorance, delusion, insanity.
  −
The process of learning and awakening is depicted by the following Chinese characters:
  −
:手+爻+手+冖+子=學 (xué) two hands holding symbols or hexagram on top, child under roof below, means learning, usually combined with 習.
  −
:羽+白=習 (xí) two wings on top white below, means a little bird flapping his or her white wings loving the joy of learning.
  −
:手+爻+手+冖+見=覺 (jué) two hands holding symbols or hexagram on top, sight under roof below, means insight and awareness.
  −
:心+吾=悟 (wù) heart or mind on left self on right, means my heart, together 覺悟 means seeing my heart directly, awake, or enlightenment.

The Chinese character for Tao is 道：
  −
:辶+首=道 (dào) walking feet on bottom head on top, means road, channel, the way. The two lines on top of head represent yin yang, the line beneath is one represent taichi giving birth to yin yang, below is the self (自, zì), depicting with the arising of this comes the arising of that, 道 is in motion with your feet, right in front of your face, the practice of just being a normal human or true human in ordinary life, an old Chinese saying says, "Master shows the door, student walks the way."
